revision.comment: /* References */http→https for [[Google Books]] and [[Google News]] using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text: {{one source|date=January 2014}} {|{{Infobox aircraft begin | name = P.1216 | image = File:BAe P1214 and P1216.png | caption = Plan-view silhouettes of British Aerospace P.1214 and P.1216 VSTOL projects | alt = }}{{Infobox aircraft type |type = Supersonic Advanced Short Take Off/Vertical Landing |national origin = UK |manufacturer = British Aerospace |designer = Former Hawker design team |first flight = |introduced = |retired = |status = |primary user = |more users = |produced = |number built = |program cost = |unit cost = |developed from = Harrier Jump Jet |variants with their own articles = F-35B }} |} The '''British Aerospace (BAe) P.1216''' was a planned supersonic Advanced [[STOVL|Short Take Off/Vertical Landing]] (ASTOVL) aircraft from the 1980s. It was designed by the former Hawker design team at Kingston upon Thames, Surrey, England that created the [[Harrier Jump Jet]] family of aircraft. The P.1216 was planned to be powered by a plenum chamber burning equipped vectored thrust engine. This used three swivelling engine nozzles rather than the four used in the Harrier. The project was most notable for its use of a twin boom layout in place of a single rear [[fuselage]]. This was intended to eliminate many of the problems caused by exhaust gases from the engine causing vibration in the rear fuselage and tail of the aircraft. (A similar solution to the three-nozzle problem was adopted in the later [[Yakovlev Yak-141|YAK-141]] prototype supersonic VTOL interceptor) The BAe P.1216 was extensively tested in model form during the 1980s, and a full-scale mock-up was viewed by British Prime Minister [[Margaret Thatcher]] during a visit to BAe's Kingston factory in December 1982. The project was extant from 1980 to 1988, and was preceded by the P.1212 series. The P.1216 was intended to meet [[Royal Air Force]] and [[Royal Navy]] requirements for an ASTOVL aircraft, as well as a possible sale to the [[United States Marine Corps]]. All these customers subsequently developed the [[F-35B]]. (Some of the design and test work on the P.1216 was used in the F-35B.) == References == *{{cite book|first=Michael|last=Pryce|title=BAe P.1216 Supersonic ASTOVL Aircraft|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=alYqtwAACAAJ|year=2011|publisher=Blue Envoy Press|isbn=978-0-9561951-1-1}} [[Category:Single-engined jet aircraft]] [[Category:British Aerospace aircraft|P.1216]] [[Category:VTOL aircraft]] {{aircraft-stub}}
